sentences.sentence: Party small talk doesn't have to be superficial, thanks to this life-changing hack.The holiday season is known for bringing dreaded cocktail party small talk.
But your conversations with colleagues, friends or family need not be awkward drudgery, according to Opinion Audio's executive producer, Annie-Rose Strasser.

In this audio essay, she reveals her no-fail solution to making every conversation accessible and exciting, no matter who shows up to the holiday party.The Times is committed to publishinga diversity of lettersto the editor.
We'd like to hear what you think about this or any of our articles.

And here's our email:letters@nytimes.com.Follow the New York Times Opinion section onFacebook,Instagram,TikTok,XandThreads.This episode of “The Opinions” was produced by Phoebe Lett with help from Kristina Samulewski.
It was edited by Kaari Pitkin and Alison Bruzek.
Original music by Isaac Jones and Carole Sabouraud.
Fact-checking and small-talk assistance by Mary Marge Locker.
Audience strategy by Shannon Busta and Kristina Samulewski.

Special thanks to Emily Berch, Lauren Kelley, Derek Arthur, Angela Fung and Stella Tan.PHOTO: (PHOTOGRAPH BY Illustration by Akshita Chandra/The New York Times; Photograph by Johner Images/Getty Images FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Party small talk doesn’t have to be superficial, thanks to this life-changing hack.The holiday season is known for bringing dreaded cocktail party small talk. But your conversations with colleagues, friends or family need not be awkward drudgery, according to Opinion Audio’s executive producer, Annie-Rose Strasser. In this audio essay, she reveals her no-fail solution to making every conversation accessible and exciting, no matter who shows up to the holiday party.The Times is committed to publishinga diversity of lettersto the editor.
